content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This CoC meets the guidelines and is approved.

I have seen a similar contribution in CoC, but this one appears just different enough with the potential for multiple operators being in the output as well as having to protect against divide by 0.  It is easily understood from the statement and can be readily accomplished in the given timeframe.  The test cases give good coverage and are correct.  I believe this CoC submission meets the requirements and I approve this.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very clear Statement and not too hard.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear statement, solvable in less  5 minutes

"You should print all the valid symbols if there is more than one, following the order indicated above and separated by space."
In reverse mode, how the player can know that the order is "- + * //" and not " + - * //" or... ?
You should forget the reverse mode for your CoC

For the fairness between languages, "//" should be changed to "/ " : because "//" is for Python and means floor... and it is not the default for most of languages. The default is "/"
Sorry, but your CoC is only  for Python coders : they will be definitely advantaged among the 26 others suggested languages
Other languages will loose their time to make a specific condition only for this case...
And moreover, the reverse mode is not acceptable following these previous conditions

* Output section: Please change "caracter" to "character".

* Are you going to add cases which require the output of / ? If so, I would suggest to mention that for division, only the integral part of the result is considered, and the fractional part is ignored.

* In Goal section, please mention that in the cases of subtraction and division, we consider a - b and a / b only, and never b - a nor b / a. Alternatively, you may add cases covering b - a and b / a.

* Please add a constraint that there is always a unique solution to every case. Cases like a = 7, b = 0, c = 7 should not appear because both + and - are valid answers.

Thanks.
Thanks. I updated the Goal and extended the problem including multiple operators as output
I can't see any specific advantage to Python. In some languages, / can work like floor division. Also, if you refer to the author's solution code, there's nothing Python-specific.
Thanks, I'll think about it.
Thanks !

I added the test case 0 0 0 - + *. What do you think? It is sufficient to infer the expected order of operators in Reverse mode?
Thanks
Oh, the commenter's account has been deleted :open_mouth: You won't get to know their feedback...

For example In PHP , '//' does not exist... 
https://www.php.net/manual/en/language.operators.arithmetic.php
There's intdiv.

Yep, or floor... but for a CoC  based on rapidity, Python users will be definitely be advantaged... it is just an eval string with a value of  an array ['-','+','*','//']...
In python, the loop will be easy. For others  languages, they will have to make a condition for this "//"
I understand that there's certain advantage to users of all languages which have the eval function. But then, changing "//" to "/" doesn't reduce that advantage a lot.

Why not ?! Let's see who will be the fastest...

But sorry, Python coders are already privileged enough over other languages...
Just by using the encoding in UTF-8  and decoding in UTF-16 for short code CoC...

Just add .replace("//", "/") :wink:

I mean you can even suggest to change + - * / to add, subtract, multiply, divide, but that still doesn't eliminate the advantage of eval.

To me, an example of a clash having the language-specific issue is when the required output can be produced without much formatting effort, e.g. printing a dictionary from Python - a lot more effort would be involved to construct the output in exactly the same format in other languages.

However, for this particular clash, while there is an advantage in using Python (and then it depends on whether the player knows how to use eval, in which case he still needs to convert the integers to strings, and that is not needed if eval is not used), I don't see an ABSOLUTE advantage.

Sorry for misrepresenting myself, but I was referring in short code mode after all.
Yes, you're right for the fastest mode.

OK!

I think eval exists for other languages like Ruby, JavaScript and Perl too?

Anyway, I have no opinion on whether to enable or disable Shortest mode for this clash. Certain languages are always advantageous in that mode.
I changed // to / and updated Goal Section
Yes, you're right ! Eval function is not implemented for many languages and, you and me know which the best language is to use for shortest mode following the CoC...

Nice change :) Please update Output section too, as now the answer may contain more than one symbol.

Please also update the constraints.

Thanks.

Done. What I have to update in constraints section?
Thanks
Some numbers are greater than 1000...
Done! :-)
